resources.string: Death, like a fingerprint, is unique to every individual. According to Barbara Karnes RN, /"The death process is a road map, like any map, there are many roads arriving at the same destination, may ways to enter the same city.\" When losing a family member or friend we seek something concrete, set in stone. You are asking yourself, \"How many months, hours, minutes?\" \"Will it be today?\" \"Death comes in its own time.\" Use this application while understanding and remembering nothing is definite or tangible. Your loved one may experience many of these symptoms or none at all.
Withdrawal - The beginning of division from the world around them. Lack of activity and interest. "A time of withdrawing from the outside of ones self and going inside

Sleep - Increase in sleep because the process of arranging ones thoughts of ones self and ones life usually occurs during sleep. Your loved one may take more frequent naps or even sleep the days away.
Communication - Communication through words can be considered part of the physical world. Touch takes over with more meaning.

Food - Humans consume food for energy to live and survive. As the human body is transitioning to die, food no longer has value. Portions decrease, hard foods of substance become more soft foods like puddings, yogurts, and soup. The hard to digest foods, like meat usually go first. Families have a hard time with this phase as they may feel their loved one is starving themselves, however, it is natural to lose their appetites.
Sleep - Your loved one is sleeping most always, but can be awakened by sound or touch. It\'s hard for them to stay awake or keep eyes open.

Disorientation - Confusion sets in and they might begin talking to unseen people in the room, especially appearing to speak to loved ones who are already deceased. It is as if one foot is on each side of each world, between life and death.
Agitation - They may pick at their bed sheets and clothes. Random arm movements or spasms. "They are losing their grounding to the earth."

Physical Changes - BP lowers, heart rate becomes abnormal and can change from 70 to 160 or can be 50 or below. Body temperature becomes feverish then chills. Skin color can become a pale blueish as their heart is no longer circulating and oxygenating the limbs consistently. Feet and hands then become colder to the touch. Breathing is inconsistent and changes frequently from high to low or vise versa. Breathing during this time can stop for up to 30 seconds and resume again. This is called apnea. There may be a rattling sound of congestion in the lungs or throat. It comes and goes and can get loader or softer depending on the position of the person.

string.b: 1 to 2 Days to Hours to Minutes Before Passing

resources.string: Rallying - A boost of energy can happen. Your loved one might talk clearly or begin to eat again. They might ask for company and even interact. "The spiritual energy for transition from this world to the next has arrived and used as a physical expression. This energy is not always as noticeable, but in hindsight, can usually be recognized."
Terminal Restlessness - Lack of oxygen can cause a person to be extremely physically restless.

Physical Changes - Breathing is even more irregular and congestion can get very loud. Eyes may appear glassy or glazed over. Hands and feet \"model\" with blotchy red or purple. Person can not be awakened.
